results.title: Pluto's Christmas tree
results.creator_credit: Jack Hannah and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: The second last entry in the theatrical Mickey Mouse series which officially began in 1928. As in many of his latter cartoons, Mickey is largely a background foil of others, in this case Pluto and Chip ‘n’ Dale. Animated by George Kreisl, Fred Moore, Bill Justice, Volus Jones. Music by Joseph S. Dubin.

results.title: Plugger
results.creator_credit: Australian Football Video, AFL and Broadcom Australia Ltd
results.brief_description: Tony Lockett’s debut in 1983 showed a young kid with potential, someone who would go on to stand alongside football greats such as Coventry, Pratt, Coleman and Hudson. The path to glory was a slow, tumultuous, and public affair. He sustained serious injuries and made numerous tribunal appearances, his every move followed in the tabloids. Now retired, Plugger has an impressive statistical history which includes: tying the 1987 Brownlow Medal with John Platten, 1987 Club Best and Fairest, winner of the John Coleman Medal in 1987 with 117 goals, leading his club’s goalkicking on six occasions - 1984, 1985, 1986, 1987, 1989 and 1990, representing Victoria three times, and passing Coventry’s record to be the leading goal kicker of all time.

results.title: Plain sailing
results.creator_credit: Martin Cohen, Robin Hughes and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Designed to assist the small businessman by emphasising the necessity of a thorough knowledge and planning before embarking on a business venture. Describes some of the do’s and don’ts that can make or break a business.

results.title: Pleasure faire
results.creator_credit: Kris Paterson, Peter Jones and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: From British Columbia, a day at a youth festival reminiscent of the folk fairs of medieval times, organised by people who choose to live outside the usual social pattern. The Pleasure Faire offered crowds a wide variety of hand-made objects—jewellery, beadwork, leatherwork, art, pottery. More than that, it provided a day of music, minstrel songs, dancing, and people participating in the spirit of the occasion, free of any commercialism or constraint. A day of joy, relived through the film.

results.title: Playtime [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Jacques Tati, Rene Silvera and Specta Films
results.brief_description: The third of Tati’s films to feature the gangling form of Monsieur Hulot, “Playtime” is a surreal, comic vision of mankind’s battle against the overwhelming depersonalisation of modern city life. Filmed upon one of the most ambitious and imaginative sets ever to grace the screen, Tati’s cinematic magnum opus took three years and a reported one million pounds to shoot. The result is a startling triumph acclaimed by the international media as Tati’s finest work. Also available on VHS [302002].

results.title: Playing the environment game
results.creator_credit: Mick Csaky and Pictures That Move
results.brief_description: One of London’s outstanding features is the historic architecture, and this film shows three groups of people fighting changes, including developers against community groups. The process of corporate land acquisition is illustrated, and the effects of this on local residents and council plans for land.

results.title: Playing Fair
results.creator_credit: Penny Ritco, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A series of four dramas for 7-12 year olds intended to promote discussion on the issues of racism, respect and equality for children. Each episode revolves around a conflict where a child is taunted and discriminated against because they are a member of a minority group. The situations are credible and expose the impact of such behaviour on children.

results.title: Walker
results.creator_credit: Alanis Obomsawin, Penny Ritco, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Playing Fair”.
Walker is a young American Indian boy who has tragically lost his parents and is now fostered by another American Indian family. His only playmate and real companion is his dog. Jamie, a lonely young white boy has been made afraid, not only of dogs, but of people who are not white. Walker ignores the racist taunts and jeerings of the older boys who have influenced Jamie, and reaches out to him. Together they find friendship and understanding as Jamie learns to conquer his fears.

results.title: Hey, Kelly!
results.creator_credit: Sook-Yin Lee, Penny Ritco, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Playing Fair”.
During a friendly game of tag, Robert calls Kelly a racist name and a fight ensues. Both Kelly and Robert are given detention, and the Principal gives them a task where they must co-operate in order to achieve the desired end. It is through this co-operation and working together, that Robert realises that he has a great deal in common with Kelly, and that her “difference” is only “skin-deep”.
